data.title: Matera
data.description: Matera, the town were I was born, is one of the oldest continuously inahabited cities of the world. Have a look at its breathtaking Sassi through my eyes.

photos.title: The Moon setting over an awakening Matera
photos.description: This 1-hour composite captures the path of the setting Moon above the Sassi of Matera as the first rays of sunlight begin to hit the ancient town.

photos.title: The Sassi "Constellation"
photos.description: As the day comes to a close, the Sassi di Matera transforms into a romantic wonderland as the evening lights twinkle like stars, illuminating the city in a picturesque manner.

photos.title: Supermoon above Matera
photos.description: In July 2022, the stunning Supermoon aligns perfectly with the bell tower of Matera's cathedral, creating a once-in-a-lifetime celestial spectacle.

photos.title: Craco, the Golden Hill
photos.description: The breathtaking view from the window of Craco's defensive tower, a ghost town nestled in the heart of southern Italy, also known as the "golden hill" for the way its fields of wheat shimmer gold under the summer sun.

photos.title: Matera Analogica
photos.description: I captured this image of Matera by using a 35mm film in my Grandpa's Rolleicord V camera. The Kodak Gold film produced stunning colors that spread across the entire picture.

photos.title: Matera o Laputa?
photos.description: In this double exposure, the clouds overlap with the ancient Sassi of Matera, giving the illusion that the city is the renowned Laputa, the flying city described in Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels.

photos.title: I Sassi di Matera
photos.description: The picture captures the ancient neighborhood of Sasso Caveoso in Matera, taken from the vantage point of Piazza San Pietro Caveoso on a warm summer day in August.

photos.title: One last glimpse of sunlight
photos.description: As the day comes to a close, the sun casts a warm glow on the bell tower of Matera's cathedral, illuminating the ancient stone structure in a beautiful orange light. I always make sure to have a cold beer and a good friend by my side to fully appreciate this stunning landscape.

photos.title: A quiet moment
photos.description: This place is now a popular destination for tourists. I was fortunate to be there on a quiet afternoon, allowing me to enjoy the tranquillity before capturing this photo.

data.title: Astrophotography
data.description: I can't help but keep looking at the sky, watching the stars makes me feel closer to infinity.

photos.title: First Quarter
photos.description: The First Quarter of the Moon in all its majestic beauty.

photos.title: Da Vinci Glow
photos.description: During the first phases of the Moon it is possible to see a pale shadow of the full disk, this is thanks to the reflected light from the earth. This phenomenon is called Da Vinci's Glow because Leonardo Da Vinci was the first one to understand its cause.

photos.title: Waxing Crescent Moon
photos.description: My favorite photo of the moon so far, another Mineral moon, this time with more balanced colors. The dark blue areas are rich in Iron, and the yellow areas contain Aluminum. I prefer the waxing crescent moon to the full moon because the Copernicus and Tycho craters are more defined thanks to the shadow of the terminator.

photos.title: Mineral Moon
photos.description: This picture showcases the mineral composition of the moon by enhancing the colors. The blue areas are rich in Iron, and the red areas contain Aluminum. These are the true colors of the moon, just saturated to make them more visible.

photos.title: Neowise Comet
photos.description: In the summer of 2020, the Neowise comet passed close to Earth and was visible for several days at the end of July. I took many shots and enjoyed the time spent searching for it and observing it in the sky.

photos.title: HDR First Quarter Moon
photos.description: This composite HDR shot captures the dark side of the Moon, which is visible during the First Quarter phase.

photos.title: Moon and Mars Conjunction
photos.description: This is one of my first pictures taken using my telescope. It captures the conjunction of the Moon and Mars, with the latter at opposition (the point in its orbit when it is opposite the Sun).

photos.title: Andromeda Galaxy
photos.description: This is my first attempt at deep space astrophotography. I used my Fujifilm X-T3 camera with an old Nikkor 135mm f3.5 lens to capture this image. Although the result is not perfect, it motivated me to invest time and money into further exploring this type of photography.

data.title: Black & White
data.description: Sometimes it's necessary to strip away the colors to see more clearly.

photos.title: Santuario di San Luca
photos.description: Bologna is renowned for its arcades. Among them, I find the arcades of the Sanctuary of San Luca to be the most captivating: they are impressive in size and have a certain allure.

photos.title: Cimelio di famiglia
photos.description: The Rolleicord V, an analog camera passed down to me by my grandfather, is my favorite camera because it is a true pleasure to use, it produces images of exceptional quality, and it always looks sleek and stylish when I use it.

photos.title: Santa Maria del Fiore
photos.description: Santa Maria del Fiore, a true jewel of Florence and the Renaissance, is renowned for its dome designed by Brunelleschi, which is the largest dome made of brick in the world and is widely considered one of the most significant architectural achievements of the Middle Ages as it set a new standard in construction and influenced the architecture of the centuries that followed.

photos.title: Matera o Laputa?
photos.description: In this double exposure, the clouds overlap with the ancient Sassi of Matera, giving the illusion that the city is the renowned Laputa, the flying city described in Jonathan Swift's Gulliver's Travels.

photos.title: Livelli
photos.description: One of Matera's most unique features is its stacked construction, where every street doubles as the roof of the house below. This is why I love to go to high vantage points and look at the labyrinth of streets and homes below me.

photos.title: Una Sera a Matera
photos.description: This girl, possibly a tourist, was calmly strolling when she spotted something in the shadows that caught her attention and she wanted to photograph. I never went to find out what it was that caught her curiosity, it will remain her secret.

photos.title: Semplice Geometria
photos.description: In the late afternoon, if you wait for the right moment, the sunlight sculpts the shapes of the Sassi's buildings into a play of light and shadow, white and black. Simple Geometry.

photos.title: Dritto nell'Abisso
photos.description: The Sassi are built on the edge of a cliff, almost as if the buildings cling to the hill to avoid falling. Just look down to perceive this constant tension.

photos.title: Il Sole e La Murgia
photos.description: The sun sets where the hill on which Matera stands, on the left, and the Murgia Materana plain, on the right, appear to meet. In reality, they never touch, the Gravina River flows between them.

photos.title: La Gravina
photos.description: In front of Matera, there is the Murgia Materana Park, separated by the canyon called Gravina, which was carved by the Gravina River. Here, our ancestors used to lead their flocks to graze.
